metadata.sermon_title: The God of Small Things: St. Bede and the Evangelical Faith
metadata.preacher: Not explicitly mentioned (Context: New York based, likely Fleming Rutledge or similar)
metadata.sermon_start_end: UP WHERE I live in New York, there has been a good deal of conversation this week about a huge front-page article in Sunday’s New York Times [...] Christ is the morning star, who when the night of this world is past, brings to his saints the promise of the light of life and opens everlasting day. AMEN.
metadata.liturgical_context: Feast Day of the Venerable Bede / Institution of a Rector
metadata.historical_context: May 2005; post-9/11 era, height of the 'liberal vs. evangelical' culture wars in the US Episcopal Church.
metadata.notes: The sermon seeks to bridge the gap between 'mainline' and 'evangelical' identities through historical and biblical reframing.

criterion_a1_imagery.analysis: The sermon employs strong, historically grounded imagery to bridge the gap between abstract theology and concrete reality. The preacher effectively uses the contrast between the 'humblest little building' at Jarrow and the 'magnificent edifice' of Durham Cathedral to illustrate the growth of the Spirit. The use of the 'plumb line' (plummet) as a central metaphor for ministry provides a tactile, visual anchor for the congregation. While the imagery is not avant-garde, it is deeply evocative of the 'sober beauty' characteristic of the Anglican tradition. The movement from the 'stench' of cultural disdain to the 'morning star' of Bede’s vision shows a high degree of sensory awareness.
quotes: The image is that of Zerubbabel standing over the construction site with a plumb line in his hand
This is the humblest little building you can imagine, put together out of stones left over from the Roman occupation
Christ is the morning star, who when the night of this world is past, brings to his saints the promise of the light of life
strengths: Effective use of architectural metaphors to explain spiritual growth.
Strong 'showing' of the historical setting of Jarrow vs. Durham.
The plumb line serves as a recurring, stabilizing visual motif.
improvement_points: The contemporary imagery (New York Times, NPR) is somewhat flat compared to the historical imagery.
Could have utilized more sensory details regarding the Babylonian exile to heighten the 'theological emergency'.
The Rockwell Kent reference might be too niche for a general audience to visualize immediately.
criterion_a1_imagery.show_vs_tell_balance: The sermon successfully 'shows' the historical and biblical scenes, though it 'tells' the theological definitions of evangelicalism quite directly.

criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.analysis: The language is exceptionally precise and exhibits high 'stewardship of language' (McEntyre). The preacher carefully deconstructs the loaded term 'evangelical,' stripping away modern political baggage to reveal its linguistic and theological roots. There is a clear effort to avoid 'Canaanite jargon' by defining terms like 'evangel' and 'semper reformanda' within the flow of the narrative. The distinction between 'fundamentalism' and 'reverence for Scripture' is handled with surgical precision. The prose is economical, yet rich in nuance, doing justice to the complexity of church history without becoming academic or dry.
quotes: The word used to refer to the solidly Protestant theology of such people as Georg Herbert... and Martin Luther
Not weighing our merits, but pardoning our offenses. That is pure evangelical theology!
Building the church today does not mean building more buildings... It means building up the family of God
strengths: Excellent re-definition of contested religious terminology.
Nuanced handling of the tension between 'liberal' and 'evangelical' identities.
Clear, authoritative voice that avoids platitudes.
improvement_points: Occasional use of 'insider' references (e.g., 'Prayer Book that all of us over-sixties grew up with') could be slightly more inclusive.
The transition between the New York Times article and the 7th century could be smoother.
The phrase 'theological emergency' is strong but could be unpacked more for the lay listener.
criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.jargon_analysis: Religious jargon is used intentionally as a tool for education; it is always explained or contextualized through historical examples.

criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.analysis: The sermon possesses a dignified, liturgical rhythm. The repetition of the refrain from Zechariah ('Not by might, nor by power...') acts as a musical 'cantus firmus' that grounds the entire performance. The sentence structure varies between short, punchy declarations and longer, flowing historical descriptions. The use of alliteration and parallelism (e.g., 'no setback... no obstacle... no opposition') creates a sense of momentum and oratorical weight. It is clearly written for the ear, with a cadence that suggests a deliberate, measured delivery suitable for a formal institution service.
quotes: Not by might, nor by power, but by my Spirit, says the Lord of hosts.
No setback can halt God’s purpose—no obstacle can block it; no opposition can defeat it.
The God of small things will build great things, not because Christians are great but because God is great.
strengths: The rhythmic repetition of the key scripture text builds rhetorical power.
Good balance of staccato statements and legato descriptions.
The closing quote from Bede provides a poetic, resonant finish.
improvement_points: The opening paragraph is somewhat 'clunky' and journalistic compared to the later poetic sections.
Some historical lists (names of saints/hymn writers) interrupt the rhythmic flow.
Could use more internal rhyme or assonance to heighten the 'musical' quality of the prose.
criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.paper_language_diagnosis: Primarily oral language; the structure suggests a preacher who understands the 'breath' of a spoken address.

domain_a_poetics_of_language.summary_language: The language is characterized by 'sober beauty' and intellectual rigor. It avoids the fluff of contemporary 'kitsch' by rooting its imagery in historical and biblical concrete realities. The preacher acts as a 'steward of the word,' carefully reclaiming the term evangelical from its cultural captors. While the opening is somewhat journalistic, the sermon ascends into a rhythmic, almost liturgical prose that effectively uses repetition and historical narrative to create a sense of timelessness and divine initiative.

criterion_b1_narrative_arc.analysis: The sermon follows a clear, if somewhat traditional, movement. It begins with a 'disruption' (the cultural disdain for evangelicals), moves through a historical and biblical 'complication' (the exile, the day of small things), and finds its 'resolution' in the promise of the Spirit. However, the arc is more argumentative than narrative. While there is a 'turning point' in the move from the Babylonian crisis to the promise of the Spirit, the tension is intellectual rather than existential. The 'plot' is the rehabilitation of a word and a ministry, which is effective for an institution service but lacks the raw dramatic tension of a 'Lowry loop'.
quotes: The media and the culture in general have made it a rule that there is a sharp division...
It was not just a social, political, and psychological crisis; it was a 'theological emergency.'
God has determined the future of the church. No setback can halt God’s purpose.
strengths: Clear movement from contemporary problem to historical solution.
The 'day of small things' serves as a strong thematic bridge.
The conclusion successfully ties the local rector's ministry to the cosmic work of God.
improvement_points: The 'upsetting of the equilibrium' is a bit external (the NY Times) rather than internal to the congregation's experience.
The middle section on Bede and Cuthbert feels slightly like a history lecture, slowing the momentum.
The transition to the 'Epistle reading' feels a bit tacked on near the end.
criterion_b1_narrative_arc.plot_diagnosis: A dynamic journey that moves from cultural critique to historical reflection to theological promise.

criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.analysis: This is the sermon's greatest strength. The preacher masterfully 'reframes' (Cilliers) the current identity crisis of the Episcopal Church through the lens of Zechariah and the history of Northumbria. The 'day of small things' in post-exilic Judah is perfectly mapped onto the 'day of small things' in a modern mainline parish. The integration is not forced; the preacher respects the 'strangeness' of the 7th century and the 6th century BC, yet makes them feel immediate. The synthesis of the 'plumb line' with the work of a new rector offers a fresh frame for the congregation to view their new ministry.
quotes: The defeated American South at its lowest ebb was not as low as Judea after the Babylonian exile.
Building the church today means something more than buildings... It means building up the family of God.
You are responding... to a genuine evangelical of the sort that was not created yesterday at the nondenominational megachurch.
strengths: Brilliant 'reframing' of the term 'evangelical' within an Anglican context.
The historical parallels (Jarrow/Durham) provide a tangible sense of 'already/not yet'.
The application to the new rector is organic and grounded in the text.
improvement_points: Could have addressed the specific context of Camden, SC more deeply beyond the 'Civil War' reference.
The connection to the 'Epistle' could be more integrated into the Zechariah framework.
The critique of 'megachurches' is a bit of a 'cheap shot' that could be more nuanced.
criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.reframing_present: The sermon offers a powerful new frame: the church is not a declining institution but a Spirit-led construction site using 'small things'.

criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.analysis: The sermon is relatively 'closed' in its theological conclusions, which is appropriate for an institution service where confidence is required. However, it leaves 'open' the specific future of Grace Church, emphasizing that the 'Spirit'—not the preacher's plan—is the actor. It avoids moralistic 'to-do' lists, instead pointing to the 'mystery' of God's work. While it doesn't leave much room for doubt or ambivalence regarding the gospel's truth, it respects the 'ambivalence of existence' by acknowledging the 'day of small things' and the 'theological emergency' of the exile.
quotes: For all I know, maybe you will have to have one too [a capital campaign]...
The God of small things will build great things, not because Christians are great but because God is great.
Whether you recognize it yet or not...
strengths: Avoids a moralistic ending; focuses on promise rather than command.
Acknowledges the reality of 'redundant churches' and decline without being defeatist.
Leaves the 'how' of the Spirit's work open to the congregation's future.
improvement_points: The theological definitions are quite 'sealed'; there is little room for the hearer to interpret 'evangelical' differently.
The ending, while beautiful, is a definitive 'Amen' that resolves all the cultural tensions raised at the start.
Could invite more 'active participation' from the hearer in the interpretation of the 'plumb line'.
criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.open_work_diagnosis: A largely monovalent work that seeks to persuade and ground, though it leaves the 'space for grace' open for the future.

domain_b_dramaturgy_of_structure.summary_structure: The structure is architecturally sound, moving from a contemporary cultural 'emergency' to a biblical and historical 'reframing'. The integration of the Zechariah text with the history of Bede and the local institution of a rector is seamless and intellectually satisfying. While the narrative arc is more didactic than dramatic, it successfully avoids the 'three-point' trap by following a thematic journey. It opens a space for the congregation to see their 'small' work as part of a 'great' divine construction project.

kitsch_diagnosis.analysis: The sermon is remarkably free of religious kitsch. It avoids 'pre-chewed' emotions and easy 'happy endings' by dwelling on the 'theological emergency' of the exile and the 'humble stones' of Jarrow. It does not offer immediate comfort but roots hope in the long, often difficult history of the church. The preacher explicitly warns against 'vainglorious exercise of human power' and 'overly romantic' views of cathedrals. The emotion feels authentic because it is tied to historical struggle and the 'sober' reality of church decline, rather than sentimental manipulation.
examples_of_kitsch: The mention of 'Rockwell Kent' is borderline sentimental, but used to illustrate a tool (plumb line) rather than a feeling.
The 'megachurch' critique is a bit of a cliché, though used for contrast.
authentic_moments: The description of the 'theological emergency' of the exile.
The honest admission that cathedrals were often centers of 'not edifying' power.
The focus on the 'humble little building' at Jarrow.
kitsch_diagnosis.recommendation: Maintain this 'sober' aesthetic; it is the best defense against the kitsch that often plagues 'special occasion' sermons.

space_for_grace_analysis.analysis: Space is opened for grace by the consistent emphasis on 'divine initiative' over 'human might.' By using the Zechariah text, the preacher creates a 'space' where the congregation's smallness is not a failure but the very site of God's activity. The sermon sustains the tension between the 'redundant' buildings of the present and the 'eternal' building of the Spirit. It avoids closing the space with a 'capital campaign' checklist, instead pointing to the 'unavailability' of the Spirit's power. However, the dogmatic certainty of the 'evangelical' definition slightly narrows the space for those who might struggle with that label.
space_for_grace_analysis.tension_sustained: The tension between the 'day of small things' and the 'magnificent edifice' is well-sustained.
space_for_grace_analysis.mystery_respected: The 'Spirit' is treated as a sovereign, mysterious actor, not a tool for church growth.
space_for_grace_analysis.moralization_vs_grace: Grace prevails; the preacher explicitly frames the Epistle as a 'promise' rather than a 'command'.
space_for_grace_analysis.recommendation: To create even more space, allow for more 'silence' or 'questions' regarding the 'theological emergencies' of the modern hearer.

overall_aesthetics.summary: This sermon is a strong example of 'Sober-Reformed' aesthetics within an Anglican liturgical framework. Its primary aesthetic power lies in its ability to 'reframe' contemporary cultural anxieties through the 'optics' of historical and biblical narratives. The preacher avoids the pitfalls of religious kitsch by grounding the message in the 'stones and plumb lines' of history rather than the 'sentiments' of modern therapeutic culture. The language is precise, rhythmic, and intellectually stimulating, honoring the 'stewardship of the word.' While the structure is more didactic than purely narrative, it creates a compelling 'event' (Immink) where the congregation is invited to see their local ministry as part of the cosmic 'Body of Christ.' The sermon successfully opens a 'space for grace' by shifting the focus from human achievement to divine initiative, making it an aesthetically and theologically coherent work.
strengths_top_3: Masterful reframing of 'evangelical' identity through historical and biblical lenses.
Precise stewardship of language that avoids jargon and kitsch.
Strong visual and tactile imagery (plumb line, Jarrow stones).
improvement_points_top_3: The narrative arc could be more existentially 'upsetting' for the local congregation.
The opening journalistic hook is less aesthetically refined than the rest of the sermon.
Greater use of 'open' questions could invite more hearer appropriation.
overall_aesthetics.comparison_with_specialists: Johan Cilliers (Reframing/Anti-Kitsch) and Thomas Long (Preacher as Witness to the Text).
overall_aesthetics.audience_analysis: Intellectually engaged mainline Christians, those wary of modern 'evangelical' branding, and those seeking historical depth.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Experiment with a more 'Lowry-esque' plot that starts with an internal congregational tension.
Deepen the sensory imagery of the 'theological emergency' to make the 'grace' even more startling.
Incorporate more 'open endings' to allow the Spirit more room to work in the hearer's imagination.
overall_aesthetics.conclusion: The sermon is an aesthetically successful 'open work of art' that uses the 'day of small things' to dismantle the 'kitsch' of modern success-driven church culture. It is a model of how to use history and scripture to provide a new 'optics' for a congregation in transition. While it leans towards the didactic, its rhythmic language and precise metaphors ensure it remains a 'happening' of the Word rather than a mere lecture.
